item.title: Nicktoons And The Dice of Destiny Adds One Of The Best Cartoons Ever Made
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Nicktoons & The Dice of Destiny is an isometric action game that pairs Hades-like combat with a mashup of Nickelodeon's roster of colorful characters. We recently learned the de facto Face That Runs The Place, SpongeBob, is joining the game's roster, but he's not nearly alone. Exclusively revealed here on GameSpot, the next Dice of Destiny character comes from a series that's beloved by fans of all ages.

Avatar: The Last Airbender's Katara is the next hero to be announced for Dice of Destiny, unleashing a full kit of spellcasting abilities on the four-player co-op game. Avatar: The Last Airbender is one of the most prestigious cartoons Nickelodeon has ever produced, with all three of its seasons earning perfect 100% scores on Rotten Tomatoes.

Nicktoons & The Dice of Destiny - Katara Reveal Trailer

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

The character reveal also provides a closer look at the game's art style. SpongeBob's typical look didn't have to change much, as it ports well into Dice of Destiny. Katara, meanwhile, has been reimagined as a shorter, squishier character to suit the game's aesthetic, much like how the game handles Leonardo, the Ninja Turtle, who is also making his way to the family game as seen below.

Katara's abilities

The waterbender naturally has a host of water-based abilities that will deal damage to enemies and/or heal allies, making Katara a reliable support character for your Nicktoons party.

  • Water Whip - Whips enemies with water, restoring her mana in the process. Leaves behind a puddle that speeds up allies and slows enemies.
  • Focus - Restores mana and provides a shield that reduces incoming damage.
  • Water Wave - Summons a massive wave that pushes enemies back while dealing damage.
  • Ice Pillar - Raises a tower of ice that shoots spinning frost discs outward in all directions.
  • Healing Pool - Creates an area-of-effect healing area for allies.
  • Frozen Prison - Freezes puddles and enemies at once, dealing damage and stopping enemies in their tracks.
  • Frozen Rain Barrage - Summons an ice storm that rains down on the battlefield.

Katara marks the third character revealed for Nicktoons & The Dice of Destiny, but it's clear several more will be unveiled soon. Can you identify anyone from the silhouettes below?

Nicktoons & The Dice of Destiny launches this fall on PC, Switch, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S. No specific release date has been announced yet.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: AAA Game Development Is Unsustainable But Generative AI Can Help, Smash Bros. Boss Says
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Video game development veteran Masahiro Sakurai, who is best known for creating the Kirby franchise and for his work on the Super Smash Bros. series, has said the current model of large-scale game development is "becoming unsustainable."

He told ITMedia as translated by IGN, "I think it is becoming unsustainable to continue producing large games on the scale that companies currently do, as it requires too much work."

Sakurai added that independent game developers are facing challenges, too. He said indie developers "need a lot of luck, effort, polish, and stand-out elements to succeed in the market."

The developer went on to say that he sees generative AI as a possible solution to help developers, especially teams that make large-scale games.

"The only effective breakthrough I can think of at the moment is generative AI. I think we are getting to the point where (AAA studios) have to change their way of working by using gen AI to improve work efficiency. I think we are in an era where only the companies that successfully respond to these changes will be able to survive," he said.

Sakurai mainly makes games for Nintendo, but his company, Sora Ltd., is not owned by the gaming giant. Nintendo of America president Doug Bowser has said he believes AI will play a role in the future of gaming, but the ""human touch" will always be necessary to make great games.

Bowser is basically echoing what Nintendo president Shuntaro Furukawa said back in 2023. At the time, the executive said Nintendo would consider leveraging AI like it would any new technology, but games will not be made by "technology alone." Mario creator Shigeru Miyamoto, meanwhile, has said Nintendo won't necessarily rush to utilize AI just because other companies may be doing so.

Sakurai is not the first person to question the sustainability of the AAA landscape, as former PlayStation boss Shawn Layden has been beating that drum for years. As for the role new AI systems can play in the future of game development, it remains to be seen how it will shake out, but developers are already using such tools to speed up development. EA Sports said this week that it created a "newly upgraded machine- learning-based pipeline" to speed up development on CFB 26. In 2024, the majority of video game developers worldwide were using AI tools to make games, despite ongoing concerns from workers.

Kingdom Come director Daniel Vavra previously spoke positively about his hope that an "AI revolution" will help his studio make games faster and more efficiently. Not everyone is so enthusiastic about the role of AI in gaming going forward, as enigmatic game developer Yoko Taro recently said "AI will make all game creators unemployed." It remains to be seen how companies adopting AI systems might impact employment. Larian Studios' Swen Vincke has embraced AI to automate tedious tasks no one wants to do.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Meta Quest 3S Xbox Edition Is Real And Available Now While Supplies Last
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Xbox and Meta are teaming up for an Xbox-themed edition of the Quest 3S VR headset. The Meta Quest 3S Xbox Edition has the same tech specs and features as the standard Meta Quest 3S 128GB model, but sports a new black and green color scheme on the headset and Touch Plus controllers. The limited-edition headset is available exclusively at Best Buy and Meta in the US. The Quest 3S Xbox Edition is only being sold in a $400 bundle with matching editions of Meta's Elite Strap and the official Xbox Wireless Controller as well as 3-month memberships for Xbox Game Pass Ultimate and Meta Horizon+.

That's actually a pretty good deal. The regular Meta Quest 3S 128GB retails for $299 and normally only includes the headset and Touch Plus controllers. The other four items in the bundle--Xbox Wireless Controller ($65), Elite Strap ($70), Game Pass Ultimate ($60), and Meta Horizon+ ($24)--are valued at $219, meaning you're "saving" $119 with this bundle. And that's without factoring in the special-edition designs of the controllers and headset. Xbox and Meta say supplies are limited, and once it sells out, it's gone for good.

Meta Quest 3S Xbox Edition

$400 | Limited Availability

Aside from the Xbox-themed skin and accessories, the model included in the bundle is identical to the standard white Quest 3S that launched last fall. That said, this is still a compelling bundle, even if you aren't currently in the Xbox ecosystem. The Quest 3S supports Xbox Cloud Gaming, which means you can stream hundreds of Xbox games while using the headset's lenses as a personal display. Xbox's streaming library is locked behind Game Pass Ultimate. The 3-month subscription included here is a prepaid voucher, not a trial, so anyone can redeem it, even active members.

With the subscription and official Xbox Wireless Controller, this bundle has everything needed to play many of Microsoft's biggest games--provided you have a stable Wi-Fi connection. An actual Xbox system isn't necessary, but console owners have the added benefit of streaming their full game libraries via remote play.

Along with the vast library of games offered by Xbox Cloud Gaming, new Quest 3S owners will be able to claim and keep two virtual reality games each month from the Meta Store with Meta Horizon+. So you'll get six free games throughout the trial. Similar to Game Pass, a rotating library of Quest games is also available to active subscribers.

The Meta Quest 3S is a standalone VR headset, meaning it's equipped with all the necessary hardware to play or cloud stream games without the need for an external gaming console, PC, or smartphone. That said, you can also easily connect the Quest 3S to your PC to play VR games that require more hardware power; you just need a compatible high-speed data cable.

The Meta Quest 3S is the entry-level version of the flagship Quest 3 and launched as a replacement for the Quest 2. Like the Quest 3, it has a Qualcomm Snapdragon XR2 Gen 2 chipset and 8GB RAM. The major difference between the two is their displays. The Quest 3S uses 1832 x 1920 Fresnel lenses, the same type found in the Meta Quest 2, whereas the Quest 3 sports 2064 x 2208 pancake lenses for sharper visuals and better clarity. Additionally, the Quest 3S omits the depth sensor and offers a slightly narrower field of view. However, the Quest 3S has a bit better battery life, getting about 2.5 hours on a full charge compared to the standard Quest 3's two hours. Both offer full-color passthrough viewing modes.

It's worth noting that the Meta Quest 3S is also available in a 256GB version. While the Xbox Edition is not available in this configuration, those who want a larger internal storage space can pick up the standard Meta Quest 3S 256GB with an Elite Strap for $460 at Amazon. The Meta Quest 3--which, again, is almost identical specs-wise to the Meta Quest 3S but has a noticeably better display--is also available in a 512GB model for $500. All of these models include the Touch Controllers and a 3-month Meta Horizon+ subscription.

Meta Quest Bundles

  • Meta Quest 3S Xbox Edition 128GB Bundle -- $400
    • Includes Elite Strap, Xbox Wireless Controller, 3-Month Game Pass Ultimate
  • Meta Quest 3S 128GB + Elite Strap -- $360 ($370)
  • Meta Quest 3S 128GB -- $300
  • Meta Quest 3S 256GB + Elite Strap -- $460 ($470)
  • Meta Quest 3S 256GB -- $400
  • Meta Quest 3 512GB -- $500 | Also at Best Buy

The collaboration with Meta comes on the heels of ROG Xbox Ally and ROG Xbox Ally X reveal. Similar to the new Meta Quest 3S, the pair of handheld Windows PCs offer an Xbox spin on an existing product--though the handhelds feature a retooled design and different specs compared to current Asus ROG Ally handhelds. The ROG Xbox Ally handhelds are slated to launch this holiday.
